title: The Upcycled Clinic: A global ethnography of material creativity in contemporary medicine
descriptions:
The Upcycled Clinic is a groundbreaking global ethnography project that aims to address the issue of wastefulness in medicine by exploring creative material engagement in contemporary healthcare settings. This project will consist of five sub-projects located in Antarctica, Ghana, the Netherlands, the U.S, and the U.K, involving a diverse group of participants including ethnographers, cleaners, and laundry staff. Through the use of fieldwork, interviews, and analysis of open datasets, the project seeks to understand the conditions that facilitate innovation and improvisation in the clinic.

By moving beyond the traditional focus on patient encounters, this project will contribute to the development of new methods for reusing and sharing research material, while also advancing theories of materiality and addressing questions of resilience and innovation in the workplace. The practical outcomes of this research will include articulating the conditions for healthcare creativity and identifying local solutions to wastefulness and shortage in medical settings.

Overall, The Upcycled Clinic represents a unique opportunity to explore the potential for repurposing in the clinic and to develop a globally oriented understanding of improvisation in healthcare. This project has the potential to make a significant impact on healthcare practices and contribute to the broader field of medical anthropology.
